commit_message:
Start task RPC service before waiting

If the TaskServer RPC service is not started before the launcher waits
for its completion, then on shutdown it could result in a hang:

    WARNING oslo_messaging.server Possible hang: stop is waiting for start to complete

This is a port of the fix for Sahara bug #1546119.

Change-Id: I083a85c2ff53364535ac8658677ffa69f4318593
Closes-bug: #1705543
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/55/485755/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: taskserver = server.TaskServer() launcher = service.launch( taskserver, ) taskserver.start() launcher.wait()

commit_message:
Add table_exists in database upgrade script

Before creating tables in database, we should add table_exists in script
if table does not exist, start creating

Change-Id: Ic06a591e0337349a8fd0c6f88732310bbb5c3fc0
Closes-Bug: #1742019
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/96/531696/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ctx = op.get_context() con = op.get_bind() table_exists = ctx.dialect.has_table(con.engine, 'transport_keys') if not table_exists: op.create_table( 'transport_keys', sa.Column('id', sa.String(length=36), nullable=False), sa.Column('created_at', sa.DateTime(), nullable=False), sa.Column('updated_at', sa.DateTime(), nullable=False), sa.Column('deleted_at', sa.DateTime(), nullable=True), sa.Column('deleted', sa.Boolean(), nullable=False), sa.Column('status', sa.String(length=20), nullable=False), sa.Column('plugin_name', sa.String(length=255), nullable=False), sa.Column('transport_key', sa.Text(), nullable=True), sa.PrimaryKeyConstraint('id') )
deleted_lines: op.create_table( 'transport_keys', sa.Column('id', sa.String(length=36), nullable=False), sa.Column('created_at', sa.DateTime(), nullable=False), sa.Column('updated_at', sa.DateTime(), nullable=False), sa.Column('deleted_at', sa.DateTime(), nullable=True), sa.Column('deleted', sa.Boolean(), nullable=False), sa.Column('status', sa.String(length=20), nullable=False), sa.Column('plugin_name', sa.String(length=255), nullable=False), sa.Column('transport_key', sa.Text(), nullable=True), sa.PrimaryKeyConstraint('id') )

commit_message:
Use oslo.db options for database sync and upgrade

Enables oslo.db optionsfor barbican-db-manage. Also fixes
foreign key constraint names on initial creation so that
migrations work with both InnoDB and MySQL Cluster (NDB).

Change-Id: I69a8cfd812cec72531aa0a94bf719eeaf92beac6
Depends-On: I9f1fd2a87fdf75332de2339d3ff4f08ce9220dcf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/65/463865/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_db import options as db_options db_options.set_defaults(conf)

commit_message:
OpenStack cloud driver added

This change introduces OpenStack cloud driver based
on the openstacksdk. The goal is to interface the Redfish
server to the OpenStack-managed nodes (e.g. virtual
baremetal nodes).

Documentation for this change comes with patch
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523445/

Story: 1741052
Task: 12048
Change-Id: Iaed42435c27c8624c6a1a24ef886f7a0ec0937ea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sushy-tools refs/changes/79/523879/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Copyright 2017 Red Hat, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from sushy_tools.emulator.clouds.base import AbstractCloudDriver from sushy_tools.error import FishyError import os_client_config from novaclient import exceptions class OpenStackCloudDriver(AbstractCloudDriver): """OpenStack cloud driver""" BOOT_DEVICE_MAP = { 'Pxe': 'network', 'Hdd': 'hd', 'Cd': 'cdrom', } BOOT_DEVICE_MAP_REV = {v: k for k, v in BOOT_DEVICE_MAP.items()} def __init__(self, os_cloud, readonly=False): self._nc = os_client_config.make_client('compute', cloud=os_cloud) self._os_cloud = os_cloud def _get_instance(self, identity): try: instance = self._nc.servers.list(search_opts={'name': identity}) except exceptions.NotFound: instance = None if instance and len(instance) == 1: return instance[0] msg = ('Error finding instance UUID by name "%(identity)s" at OS cloud ' '%(os_cloud)s"' % {'identity': identity, 'os_cloud': self._os_cloud}) raise FishyError(msg) def _get_flavor(self, identity): instance = self._get_instance(identity) flavor = self._nc.flavors.get(instance.flavor['id']) return flavor @property def domains(self): """Return available instances :returns: list of instance names. """ return [node.name for node in self._nc.servers.list()] def uuid(self, identity): """Get instance UUID by instance name :returns: instance UUID """ instance = self._get_instance(identity) return instance.id def power_state(self, identity, state=None): """Get/Set instance power state :returns: `True` if power is UP and `False` otherwise """ instance = self._get_instance(identity) if not state: return 'On' if instance.status == 'ACTIVE' else 'Off' try: if state in ('On', 'ForceOn'): if instance.status == 'SHUTOFF': self._nc.servers.start(instance) elif state == 'ForceOff': if instance.status == 'ACTIVE': self._nc.servers.stop(instance) elif state == 'GracefulShutdown': if instance.status == 'ACTIVE': self._nc.servers.stop(instance) elif state == 'GracefulRestart': if instance.status == 'ACTIVE': self._nc.servers.reboot(instance) elif state == 'ForceRestart': if instance.status == 'ACTIVE': self._nc.servers.reboot(instance) elif state == 'Nmi': if instance.status == 'ACTIVE': self._nc.servers.trigger_crash_dump(instance) except exceptions.Conflict: # This can happen if we get two requests to start a server in # short succession. The instance may then be in a powering-on # state, which means it is invalid to start it again. pass except Exception as e: msg = ('Error changing power state at libvirt URI "%(uri)s": ' '%(error)s' % {'uri': self.uri, 'error': e}) raise FishyError(msg) def boot_device(self, identity, boot_source=None): """Get/Set instance boot device name :returns: boot device name as `str` """ instance = self._get_instance(identity) if boot_source: try: target = self.BOOT_DEVICE_MAP[boot_source] except KeyError: msg = ('Unknown power state requested: ' '%(boot_source)s' % {'boot_source': boot_source}) raise FishyError(msg) if target == 'network': self._nc.servers.set_meta_item(instance, 'libvirt:pxe-first', '1') else: self._nc.servers.set_meta_item(instance, 'libvirt:pxe-first', '') else: if instance.metadata.get('libvirt:pxe-first'): boot_source = self.BOOT_DEVICE_MAP_REV['network'] else: boot_source = self.BOOT_DEVICE_MAP_REV['hd'] return boot_source def boot_mode(self, identity, boot_source=None): """Get/Set instance boot mode - BIOS vs UEFI :returns: boot mode """ def total_memory(self, identity): """Get instance total memory :returns: available RAM in GB as `int` """ flavor = self._get_flavor(identity) return int(flavor.ram / 1024) def total_cpus(self, identity): """Get instance total count of available CPUs :returns: available CPU count as `int` """ flavor = self._get_flavor(identity) return flavor.vcpus

commit_message:
Dev env setup docs improved for auth setup.

Dev environment setup now requires the setting up of an authentication
environement (e.g. Keystone). Improved the dev env set up doc to show
how to check a fresh install for success, with and without the authentication
enabled.

Change-Id: Id3198090d8f7ba16de82d944e5c7f499c6558115
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/66/506966/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: An instance of barbican will be listening on ``http://localhost:9311``. Use the following simple command to check whether the default deployment was successful. .. code-block:: bash curl -v -H 'Accept: application/json' http://localhost:9311 Note that the default configuration requires an authenticated context, which means a keystone token is required in the ``X-Auth-Token`` header. To enable authentication, configure Barbican with Keystone auth. For more information, see the :doc:`Keystone Configuration </configuration/keystone>` page. Use the following command after you have an authenticated context enabled, to check whether the default deployment was successful.
deleted_lines: An instance of barbican will be listening on ``http://localhost:9311``. Note that the default configuration uses the unauthenticated context. This means that requests should include the ``X-Project-Id`` header instead of including a keystone token in the ``X-Auth-Token`` header. For example:For more information on configuring Barbican with Keystone auth see the :doc:`Keystone Configuration </configuration/keystone>` page.

commit_message:
Added symmetric key generation to IPAVaultPlugin

Change-Id: I6b02eaad349645cc67685445312dc125212396dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/33/431333/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import base64 GENERATED = "generated" VALID_KEY_SIZES = { sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA1: {'default': 160, 'minimum': 160}, sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA256: {'default': 256, 'minimum': 256}, sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA384: {'default': 384, 'minimum': 384}, sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA512: {'default': 512, 'minimum': 512}, sstore.KeyAlgorithm.AES: {'default': 256, 'minimum': 128, 'valid': [128, 192, 256]} } algorithm = self._map_algorithm(key_spec.alg) if algorithm is None: raise AlgorithmNotSupported(key_spec.alg) key_size = key_spec.bit_length or 0 key_size = self._get_valid_key_size(algorithm, key_size) key_spec.bit_length = key_size data = base64.urlsafe_b64encode(os.urandom(key_size)) secret_dto = sstore.SecretDTO( type=sstore.SecretType.SYMMETRIC, secret=data, key_spec=key_spec, content_type=None ) meta_dict = self.store_secret(secret_dto) return {IPAVaultPlugin.ALG: key_spec.alg, IPAVaultPlugin.BIT_LENGTH: key_spec.bit_length, IPAVaultPlugin.SECRET_MODE: key_spec.mode, IPAVaultPlugin.KEY_ID: meta_dict[IPAVaultPlugin.KEY_ID], IPAVaultPlugin.GENERATED: True} if algorithm is None: return None if algorithm.lower() == sstore.KeyAlgorithm.AES.lower(): return sstore.KeyAlgorithm.AES elif algorithm.lower() == sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA1.lower(): return sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA1 elif algorithm.lower() == sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA256.lower(): return sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA256 elif algorithm.lower() == sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA384.lower(): return sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA384 elif algorithm.lower() == sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA512.lower(): return sstore.KeyAlgorithm.HMACSHA512 else: return None @staticmethod def _get_valid_key_size(algorithm, key_size): if not IPAVaultPlugin.VALID_KEY_SIZES[algorithm]: raise AlgorithmNotSupported(algorithm) default = IPAVaultPlugin.VALID_KEY_SIZES[algorithm]['default'] minimum = IPAVaultPlugin.VALID_KEY_SIZES[algorithm]['minimum'] if key_size == 0: return default if key_size < minimum: raise KeySizeTooSmall(algorithm, key_size, minimum) if 'valid' in IPAVaultPlugin.VALID_KEY_SIZES[algorithm]: valid_sizes = IPAVaultPlugin.VALID_KEY_SIZES[algorithm]['valid'] for valid_size in valid_sizes: if key_size == valid_size: return key_size raise InvalidKeySize(algorithm, key_size) return key_size class AlgorithmNotSupported(IPAVaultPluginNotSupportedException): message = u._("Algorithm not supported by IPA Vault Plugin") def __init__(self, algorithm): if not algorithm: message = self.message else: message = u._("Algorithm (alg) not supported by IPA Vault Plugin" ).format(alg=algorithm) super(AlgorithmNotSupported, self).__init__(message) class KeySizeTooSmall(exception.BarbicanHTTPException): status_code = 400 def __init__(self, algorithm, keysize, minimum): message = u._( "Algorithm {alg} requires a bit length of at least {min} bits, " "{bits} requested.").format( alg=algorithm, min=minimum, bits=keysize) super(KeySizeTooSmall, self).__init__(message, message) class InvalidKeySize(exception.NotSupported): status_code = 400 def __init__(self, algorithm, keysize): message = u._("Invalid key size {bits} for algorithm {alg}.").format( alg=algorithm, bits=keysize) super(InvalidKeySize, self).__init__(message, message)
deleted_lines: This will be done in a subsequent commit. raise IPAVaultPluginNotSupportedException( u._("Symmetric key generation is not yet supported for the" " IPA Vault plugin.")) return None

commit_message:
add ipavault plugin

We are adding a new secret store plugin to integrate with
IPA Vault rather than going to the KRA directly.

Co-Authored-By: Juan Antonio Osorio Robles <jaosorior@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iffeaa64ff24172387d8df64638c077aed4d80b4b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/25/426825/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2017 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import os import uuid from oslo_config import cfg from ipalib import api from ipalib.constants import FQDN from ipalib.errors import NotFound from barbican.common import config from barbican.common import exception from barbican.common import utils from barbican import i18n as u import barbican.plugin.interface.secret_store as sstore CONF = config.new_config() LOG = utils.getLogger(__name__) ipavault_plugin_group = cfg.OptGroup(name='ipavault_plugin', title="IPA Vault Plugin Options") ipavault_plugin_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('principal', default='barbican/' + FQDN, help=u._('Principal for authentication')), cfg.StrOpt('krb5config', help=u._('Kerberos krb5.conf override')), cfg.StrOpt('keytab', default='/etc/barbican/barbican.keytab', help=u._('Kerberos keytab for auth')), cfg.StrOpt('ccache', help=u._('Kerberos ccache, e,g. FILE:/path/to/ccache')), cfg.StrOpt('ipa_confdir', help=u._('IPA confdir override')), cfg.StrOpt('ipa_context', default='cli', help=u._('IPA bootstrap context')), cfg.BoolOpt('debug', default=False, help=u._('Debug mode for ipalib')), cfg.StrOpt('plugin_name', help=u._('User friendly plugin name'), default='IPA Vault'), ] CONF.register_group(ipavault_plugin_group) CONF.register_opts(ipavault_plugin_opts, group=ipavault_plugin_group) config.parse_args(CONF) class FreeIPA(object): """FreeIPA wrapper.""" def __init__(self, krb5config=None, keytab=None, ccache=None, api=api, ipa_context='cli', ipa_confdir=None, ipa_debug=False): self._krb5config = krb5config self._keytab = keytab self._ccache = ccache self._api = api self._ipa_config = dict( context=ipa_context, debug=ipa_debug ) if ipa_confdir is not None: self._ipa_config['confdir'] = ipa_confdir self._bootstrap() @property def Command(self): return self._api.Command def _bootstrap(self): if not self._api.isdone('bootstrap'): # set client keytab env var for authentication if self._keytab is not None: os.environ['KRB5_CLIENT_KTNAME'] = self._keytab if self._ccache is not None: os.environ['KRB5CCNAME'] = self._ccache if self._krb5config is not None: os.environ['KRB5_CONFIG'] = self._krb5config # TODO(alee) - band-aid for "A PKCS #11 module returned # CKR_DEVICE_ERROR" # https://github.com/avocado-framework/avocado/issues/1112#issuecomment-206999400 os.environ['NSS_STRICT_NOFORK'] = 'DISABLED' self._api.bootstrap(**self._ipa_config) self._api.finalize() def __enter__(self): if not self._api.Backend.rpcclient.isconnected(): self._api.Backend.rpcclient.connect() return self def __exit__(self, exc_type, exc_val, exc_tb): if self._api.Backend.rpcclient.isconnected(): self._api.Backend.rpcclient.disconnect() class IPAVaultPlugin(sstore.SecretStoreBase): """Implementation of the secret store plugin with an IPA Vault backend.""" ALG = "alg" BIT_LENGTH = "bit_length" KEY_ID = "key_id" SECRET_MODE = "secret_mode" def __init__(self, conf=CONF): LOG.debug("starting IPAVaultPlugin init") self.plugin_name = conf.ipavault_plugin.plugin_name self.principal = conf.ipavault_plugin.principal self.ipa = FreeIPA( keytab=conf.ipavault_plugin.keytab, ccache=conf.ipavault_plugin.ccache, ipa_confdir=conf.ipavault_plugin.ipa_confdir, ipa_debug=conf.ipavault_plugin.debug, ipa_context=conf.ipavault_plugin.ipa_context, krb5config=conf.ipavault_plugin.krb5config, ) with self.ipa: self.logger.info(repr(self.ipa.Command.ping())) LOG.debug("completed IPAVaultPlugin init") def get_plugin_name(self): return self.plugin_name def store_secret(self, secret_dto): """Store a secret in the Vault Returns a dict with the relevant metadata (which in this case is just the key_id """ key = uuid.uuid4().hex value = secret_dto.secret with self.ipa as ipa: ipa.Command.vault_add(key, service=self.principal, ipavaulttype=u"standard") ipa.Command.vault_archive(key, data=value, service=self.principal) meta_dict = {IPAVaultPlugin.KEY_ID: key} self._store_secret_attributes(meta_dict, secret_dto) return meta_dict def get_secret(self, secret_type, secret_metadata): """Retrieve a secret from the IPA Vault """ key_id = secret_metadata[IPAVaultPlugin.KEY_ID] key_spec = sstore.KeySpec( alg=secret_metadata.get(IPAVaultPlugin.ALG, None), bit_length=secret_metadata.get(IPAVaultPlugin.BIT_LENGTH, None), mode=secret_metadata.get(IPAVaultPlugin.SECRET_MODE, None), passphrase=None ) with self.ipa as ipa: try: result = ipa.Command.vault_retrieve(key_id, service=self.principal) secret = result[u'result'][u'data'] except NotFound: # TODO(alee) Figure out what to do here secret = None return sstore.SecretDTO( type=secret_type, secret=secret, key_spec=key_spec, content_type=None, transport_key=None) def delete_secret(self, secret_metadata): """Delete a secret from the KRA There is currently no way to delete a secret in Dogtag. We will be implementing such a method shortly. """ pass def generate_symmetric_key(self, key_spec): """Generate a symmetric key The KRA interface to generate a symmetric key has not yet been exposed in thr IPA Vault interface. Until that happens, we will generate the key here and store the key in the IPA Vault. This will be done in a subsequent commit. """ raise IPAVaultPluginNotSupportedException( u._("Symmetric key generation is not yet supported for the" " IPA Vault plugin.")) def generate_asymmetric_key(self, key_spec): """Generate an asymmetric key. The KRA interface to generate an asymmetric key has not yet been exposed in thr IPA Vault interface. Until that happens, we will generate the key here and store the key in the IPA Vault. This will be done in a subsequent commit. """ raise IPAVaultPluginNotSupportedException( u._("Asymmetric key generation is not yet supported for the" " IPA Vault plugin.")) def generate_supports(self, key_spec): """Key generation supported? Specifies whether the plugin supports key generation with the given key_spec. For now, we will just check the algorithm. """ return self._map_algorithm(key_spec.alg) is not None def store_secret_supports(self, key_spec): """Key storage supported? Specifies whether the plugin supports storage of the secret given the attributes included in the KeySpec """ return True @staticmethod def _map_algorithm(algorithm): """Map Barbican algorithms to the IPA Vault algorithms. Note that only algorithms supported by IPA Vault will be mapped. """ return None class IPAVaultPluginNotSupportedException(exception.NotSupported): message = u._("Operation not supported by IPA Vault Plugin") def __init__(self, msg=None): if not msg: message = self.message else: message = msg super(IPAVaultPluginNotSupportedException, self).__init__(message)

commit_message:
Adding a plugin for Hashicorp Vault

With patch >=6 this actually works with Barbican in Devstack
Where "works" = Correctly stores and retreives key material
in Hashicorp Vault.

Still needs secret generation and of course tests.

Change-Id: Iff70a8de35522d510f16af6436d5d34700d31f08
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/09/438009/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: vault_plugin = barbican.plugin.vault_secret_store:VaultSecretStore

commit_message:
Adding Tests to Project Quota Management by Serv Admin User

The User with the service admin role in barbican should be able to
successfully GET, SET and DELETE Project Quotas of other tenant id
or project ids. These tests are missing in the functional tests
since the current tests only check the features executed by
by same user and not by the service admin user.

Change-Id: I8785b121a0682ad0ccb1124814392ed1f841c6fa

commit_message:
Remove log translations

Log messages are no longer being translated. This removes all use of
the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify logging and to
avoid confusion with new contributions.
see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/446762/ for the reason.

Change-Id: I24389a80491328f4aa2b1e50e8c1e4b0bfb82e19
Depends-On: I7d3bd59cf95d9e10c2d578b63dc60313f1d09282

commit_message:
Added tempest.test_plugins to barbican setup.cfg

Tempest plugin containing tests used to verify
the functionality of a barbican installation.
The barbican_tempest_plugin tests the barbican quota API,
which requires the existence of the 'key-manager:service-admin'
role in barbican.

Change-Id: I6251bcbbe37362bfd7f494c514b2b39f852bbce0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/47/442947/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tempest.test_plugins = neutron_tests = barbican.tests.tempest.plugin:BarbicanTempestPlugin

commit_message:
Add guru meditation report for barbican

Oslo_reports enables OpenStack projects to dump Guru Meditation
Reports with useful debugging information to files or stderr.
So we introduce it into barbican.

Change-Id: Ibe1323a27b27bfdc2cecb24429e2197b0cd67e54
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/60/345660/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright (c) 2014 OpenStack Foundation Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. Guru Meditation Reports ======================= Barbican contains a mechanism whereby developers and system administrators can generate a report about the state of a running Barbican executable. This report is called a *Guru Meditation Report* (*GMR* for short). Generating a GMR ---------------- A *GMR* can be generated by sending the *USR2* signal to any Barbican process with support (see below). The *GMR* will then be outputted as standard error for that particular process. For example, suppose that ``barbican-api`` has process id ``8675``, and was run with ``2>/var/log/barbican/barbican-api-err.log``. Then, ``kill -USR2 8675`` will trigger the Guru Meditation report to be printed to ``/var/log/barbican/barbican-api-err.log``. Structure of a GMR ------------------ The *GMR* is designed to be extensible; any particular executable may add its own sections. However, the base *GMR* consists of several sections: Package Shows information about the package to which this process belongs, including version informations. Threads Shows stack traces and thread ids for each of the threads within this process. Green Threads Shows stack traces for each of the green threads within this process (green threads don't have thread ids). Configuration Lists all the configuration options currently accessible via the CONF object for the current process. Adding Support for GMRs to New Executables ------------------------------------------ Adding support for a *GMR* to a given executable is fairly easy. First import the module: .. code-block:: python from oslo_reports import guru_meditation_report as gmr from barbican import version Then, register any additional sections (optional): .. code-block:: python TextGuruMeditation.register_section('Some Special Section', some_section_generator) Finally (under main), before running the "main loop" of the executable (usually ``service.server(server)`` or something similar), register the *GMR* hook: .. code-block:: python TextGuruMeditation.setup_autorun(version) Extending the GMR ----------------- As mentioned above, additional sections can be added to the GMR for a particular executable. For more information, see the inline documentation under :mod:`oslo.reports`

commit_message:
Use 'project' instead of 'tenant' when switching to openstackclient
command

We tend to use 'project' rather than 'tenant' when switching to
openstackclient command, such as:

  openstack role add --user <user> --project <project> <role>

Change-Id: I0b6b15531486a471bbb4b0da6957203e4641d3cf

commit_message:
Sub pycrypto with cryptography in dogtag

pycrypto is no longer maintained [1]. This patch rewrites functions
using pycrypto and replaces them with the cryptography equivalent for
the dogtag plugin

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113568

Change-Id: Ic230356385f837c19e0d031bfb40e811a1ecef4d

commit_message:
Add api documentation for transport keys

This patch adds api documentation for transport keys. It also
provides documentation on how to add a transport key to a
Secret.

Change-Id: I7307c135a9e1c92a69d8d97c66f9374e2e33b51c
Closes-Bug: #1459783
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/27/506827/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: nsport Key API - User Guide ****************************** Transport keys are used for wrapping secrets in transit to and from clients when storing and retrieving secrets. If you would like to learn more in detail about :ref:`transport key parameters <transport_key_parameters>`, :ref:`responses <transport_key_response_attributes>`, and :ref:`status codes <transport_key_status_codes>` you can reference the :doc:`transport key reference <../reference/transport_keys>'' documentation. This guide will assume you will be using a local running development environment of Barbican. If you need assistance with getting set up, please reference the :doc:`development guide </setup/dev>`. .. _create_transport_key: How to Create a Transport Key ############################# In order to create a transport key we must provide 2 parameters, the plugin we will be using as well as the actual transport key. .. code-block:: bash curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" \ -d '{"plugin_name": "crypto","transport_key": "==xntwq"}' \ http://localhost:9311/v1/transport_keys This should provide a response as follows: .. code-block:: bash {"transport_key_ref": "http://10.0.2.15:9311/v1/transport_keys/85fb7ecb-cb99-4d75-a2dd-e1d07695cb3d"} This is our transport key reference. We will need this in order to retrieve the transport key in the following steps. How to Retrieve a Transport Key ############################### To retrieve the transport key we have created we will need to know the transport key reference provided via the initial creation (See :ref:`How to Create a Transport Key <create_transport_key>`.) All transport keys can be listed using the following command .. code-block:: bash curl -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" http://localhost:9311/v1/transport_keys/ This should provide a similar response if there are keys present and you have the proper permissions to view them. .. code-block:: bash {"transport_keys": ["http://10.0.2.15:9311/v1/transport_keys/4112a2d3-06fc-46ed-8e35-bda07165e7d4", "http://10.0.2.15:9311/v1/transport_keys/27c54001-b9ff-4c14-8713-d6cfeedf6ea4", "http://10.0.2.15:9311/v1/transport_keys/85fb7ecb-cb99-4d75-a2dd-e1d07695cb3d"], "total": 3} In order to obtain the actual transport key along with its metadata we do the following: .. code-block:: bash curl -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" http://localhost:9311/v1/transport_keys/4112a2d3-06fc-46ed-8e35-bda07165e7d4 This should provide a response as follows: .. code-block:: bash {"status": "ACTIVE", "created_at": "2015-12-29 06:21:41", "deleted": false, "transport_key": "abc", "updated_at": "2015-12-29 06:21:41", "plugin_name": "crypto", "deleted_at": null, "id": "4112a2d3-06fc-46ed-8e35-bda07165e7d4"} How to Delete a Transport Key ############################# To delete a transport key we will need to know the transport key reference provided via the initial creation (See :ref:`How to Create a Transport Key <create_transport_key>`.) .. code-block:: bash curl -X DELETE -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" http://localhost:9311/v1/transport_keys/4112a2d3-06fc-46ed-8e35-bda07165e7d4 No response will be provided. This is expected behavior! If you do receive a response, something went wrong and you will have to address that before moving forward. (For more information visit :ref:`DELETE /v1/transport_keys/{uuid} <delete_transport_keys>`.) Using a Transport Key with Secret ################################# TODO

commit_message:
WIP: PKCS11 key generation: Add CKM_GENERIC_KEY for generate HMAC

Barbican currently uses the key type AES for HMAC signing, while
the pkcs11 standard v2.40 specifies GENERIC SECRET [1].
This causes key signing to fail.

This patch allows the user to select between AES an GENERIC SECRET
during HMAC generation using pkcs11_key_generation.py

TODO:
- Should both types still
- add functionality to barbican_manage.py

[1] http://docs.oasis-open.org/pkcs11/pkcs11-curr/v2.40/os/pkcs11-curr-v2.40-os.pdf
p.69

Partial-Bug: #1704141

Change-Id: I4172bc54e6f29419155e3ac0ce78c6d0d1b6eaf3

commit_message:
WIP: PKCS11: Add CKM_GENERIC_SECRET

Barbican currently uses the key type AES for HMAC signing, while
the pkcs11 standard v2.40 specifies GENERIC SECRET [1].
This causes key signing to fail.

This patch introduces GENERIC SECRET to p11 crypto and pkcs11,
while maintaining compatibility with the existing AES implementation.

TODO:
- Should both types still be supported?

[1] http://docs.oasis-open.org/pkcs11/pkcs11-curr/v2.40/os/pkcs11-curr-v2.40-os.pdf
p.69

Partial-Bug: #1704141

Change-Id: I00089fe08f4533b8ce0de42ee553af6838c7c78d

Setting the attribute CKA_EXTRACTABLE manually for key unwrapping results in

commit_message:
WIP: PKCS11: Use correct attributes for key unwrapping

Setting the attribute CKA_EXTRACTABLE manually for key unwrapping results in
CKR_ATTRIBUTE_READ_ONLY error. This error occurs due because that CKA_EXTRACTABLE
is already set by PKCS#11 automatically, as specified in the PKCS11 standard.

"The CKA_EXTRACTABLE attribute is by default set to CK_TRUE." [1]

[1] http://docs.oasis-open.org/pkcs11/pkcs11-base/v2.40/os/pkcs11-base-v2.40-os.pdf
p. 132 - Section 5.13

Closed-Bug: #1704128

Change-Id: I41aebde9db072850f082af68ae543b7c4a898e68
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/88/483388/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
WIP: Use correct AES_GCM header in pkcs11

Currently barbican specifices its AES_GCM header based on the pkcs11
v2.40 draft [2] but it should be the header of pkcs11
v2.40 final [1].
This causes the error: CKR_MECHANISM_PARAM_INVALID mechanism length invalid
(expected 40, provided 48) as reported in Barbican bug #1613989 [3].

The draft specifies the variable CK_ULONG ulIvBits;
while the current version of 2.40 does not.

[1] http://docs.oasis-open.org/pkcs11/pkcs11-curr/v2.40/os/pkcs11-curr-v2.40-os.pdf
p. 80 - section 2.12.3
[2] https://www.oasis-open.org/committees/document.php?document_id=55657&wg_abbrev=pkcs11
[3] https://bugs.launchpad.net/barbican/+bug/1613989

Closes-Bug: #1613989

Change-Id: Ia4b4c59466dbe91f84a3992dc7cb9761b4818004

commit_message:
Add granular placement policy rules for aggregates

This adds the policy rules for the resource provider
aggregates GET and PUT APIs.

Note that this change also uses scope types, which are
not enforced by default (see the [oslo_policy]/enforce_scope
configuration option).

Part of blueprint granular-placement-policy

Change-Id: I2ffb8a8f1464381d7bfb1b81fb40a4689b0c80ea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/21/570621/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_policy import policy from nova.api.openstack.placement.policies import base PREFIX = 'placement:resource_providers:aggregates:%s' LIST = PREFIX % 'list' UPDATE = PREFIX % 'update' BASE_PATH = '/resource_providers/{uuid}/aggregates' rules = [ policy.DocumentedRuleDefault( LIST, base.RULE_ADMIN_API, "List resource provider aggregates.", [ { 'method': 'GET', 'path': BASE_PATH } ], scope_types=['system'] ), policy.DocumentedRuleDefault( UPDATE, base.RULE_ADMIN_API, "Update resource provider aggregates.", [ { 'method': 'PUT', 'path': BASE_PATH } ], scope_types=['system'] ), ] def list_rules(): return rules

(secrets quota + orders quota) number of secrets via order creation,
because order quota enforcer does not take into account whether the
secrets quota is full or not.

This fix enforces the secrets quota in addition to the orders quota when

commit_message:
Fix Order Quota Enforcement to Account For Secrets Quota

Currently, if secrets quota is not infinite, it is possible to create
(secrets quota + orders quota) number of secrets via order creation,
because order quota enforcer does not take into account whether the
secrets quota is full or not.

This fix enforces the secrets quota in addition to the orders quota when
creating an order.

Now, it will not be possible for an order to create more secrets if secrets
have already met their quotas.

In the near future, a more definite policy needs to be defined for the case
where an order is created when the secrets quota is full and orders quota is
not full.

Change-Id: I003bac2514632b7e01d54bf93e036bbb7d5849cf
Closes-Bug: #1535404

added_lines: --- fixes: - | Bug 1766235_: Handle HTTP headers per RFC 8187 Previously the glanceclient encoded HTTP headers as UTF-8 bytes. According to `RFC 8187`_, however, headers should be encoded as 7-bit ASCII. The glanceclient now sends all headers as 7-bit ASCII. It handles unicode strings by percent-encoding_ them before sending them in headers. .. _1766235: https://code.launchpad.net/bugs/1766235 .. _RFC 8187: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8187 .. _percent-encoding: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-2.1

commit_message:
Remove functional-identity-v3-only job

The glanceclient-dsvm-functional-identity-v3-only job is exactly
like the glanceclient-dsvm-functional job, except that it sets
the devstack config option ENABLE_IDENTITY_V2 to False.  Change
I5afcba6321f496b8170be27789bee7c9ad8eacce in devstack makes False
the default value for this option, so we already have a voting gate
job that uses identity v3.  This patch removes the redundant
non-voting identity-v3-only job.

Change-Id: I5d5550c06b179810d25a472cc423403daed43776

commit_message:
Use ksa session for cinder microversion check

[1] added a method to validate availability of a desired version of the
cinder API.  This method called into
cinderclient.client.get_highest_client_server_version to
(unsurprisingly) discover the highest available version to compare
against.  However, that routine uses a raw requests.get to access the
version document from the server.  This breaks when the endpoint URL is
using HTTPS, because nothing sets up the cert info for that call.

With this change, we work around the issue by duplicating the logic from
get_highest_client_server_version, but doing the version discovery via
the same keystoneauth1 session that's configured for use with the client
itself, thus inheriting any SSL configuration as appropriate.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/469579/

Change-Id: I4de355195281009a5979710d7f14ae8ea11d10e0
Closes-Bug: #1752152
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/557508/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_serialization import jsonutilsfrom six.moves import urllibdef _load_session(): def _get_auth(context): global _ADMIN_AUTH return _ADMIN_AUTH else: return service_auth.get_auth_plugin(context) # NOTE(efried): Bug #1752152 # This method is copied/adapted from cinderclient.client.get_server_version so # we can use _SESSION.get rather than a raw requests.get to retrieve the # version document. This enables HTTPS by gleaning cert info from the session # config. def _get_server_version(context, url): """Queries the server via the naked endpoint and gets version info. :param context: The nova request context for auth. :param url: url of the cinder endpoint :returns: APIVersion object for min and max version supported by the server """ min_version = "2.0" current_version = "2.0" _load_session() auth = _get_auth(context) try: u = urllib.parse.urlparse(url) version_url = None # NOTE(andreykurilin): endpoint URL has at least 2 formats: # 1. The classic (legacy) endpoint: # http://{host}:{optional_port}/v{1 or 2 or 3}/{project-id} # http://{host}:{optional_port}/v{1 or 2 or 3} # 3. Under wsgi: # http://{host}:{optional_port}/volume/v{1 or 2 or 3} for ver in ['v1', 'v2', 'v3']: if u.path.endswith(ver) or "/{0}/".format(ver) in u.path: path = u.path[:u.path.rfind(ver)] version_url = '%s://%s%s' % (u.scheme, u.netloc, path) break if not version_url: # NOTE(andreykurilin): probably, it is one of the next cases: # * https://volume.example.com/ # * https://example.com/volume # leave as is without cropping. version_url = url response = _SESSION.get(version_url, auth=auth) data = jsonutils.loads(response.text) versions = data['versions'] for version in versions: if '3.' in version['version']: min_version = version['min_version'] current_version = version['version'] break except cinder_exception.ClientException as e: LOG.warning("Error in server version query:%s\n" "Returning APIVersion 2.0", six.text_type(e.message)) return (cinder_api_versions.APIVersion(min_version), cinder_api_versions.APIVersion(current_version)) # NOTE(efried): Bug #1752152 # This method is copied/adapted from # cinderclient.client.get_highest_client_server_version. See note on # _get_server_version. def _get_highest_client_server_version(context, url): """Returns highest APIVersion supported version by client and server.""" min_server, max_server = _get_server_version(context, url) max_client = cinder_api_versions.APIVersion( cinder_api_versions.MAX_VERSION) return min(max_server, max_client) def _check_microversion(context, url, microversion): """Checks to see if the requested microversion is supported by the current version of python-cinderclient and the volume API endpoint. :param context: The nova request context for auth. :param url: Cinder API endpoint URL. :param microversion: Requested microversion. If not available at the given API endpoint URL, a CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable exception is raised. :returns: The microversion if it is available. This can be used to construct the cinder v3 client object. :raises: CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable if the microversion is not available. """ max_api_version = _get_highest_client_server_version(context, url) # Check if the max_api_version matches the requested minimum microversion. if max_api_version.matches(microversion): # The requested microversion is supported by the client and the server. return microversion raise exception.CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable(version=microversion) def _get_cinderclient_parameters(context): _load_session() auth = _get_auth(context) # NOTE(efried): Work around bug #1752152. Call the cinderclient() builder # in a way that just does a microversion check. cinderclient(context, microversion=microversion, check_only=True) def cinderclient(context, microversion=None, skip_version_check=False, check_only=False): :param check_only: If True, don't build the actual client; just do the setup and version checking. :raises: UnsupportedCinderAPIVersion if a major version other than 3 is requested. :raises: CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable if microversion checking is requested and the specified microversion is higher than what the service can handle. :returns: A cinderclient.client.Client wrapper, unless check_only is False. version = _check_microversion(context, url, microversion) if check_only: return
deleted_lines: def _check_microversion(url, microversion): """Checks to see if the requested microversion is supported by the current version of python-cinderclient and the volume API endpoint. :param url: Cinder API endpoint URL. :param microversion: Requested microversion. If not available at the given API endpoint URL, a CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable exception is raised. :returns: The microversion if it is available. This can be used to construct the cinder v3 client object. :raises: CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable if the microversion is not available. """ max_api_version = cinder_client.get_highest_client_server_version(url) # get_highest_client_server_version returns a float which we need to cast # to a str and create an APIVersion object to do our version comparison. max_api_version = cinder_api_versions.APIVersion(str(max_api_version)) # Check if the max_api_version matches the requested minimum microversion. if max_api_version.matches(microversion): # The requested microversion is supported by the client and the server. return microversion raise exception.CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable(version=microversion) def _get_cinderclient_parameters(context): global _ADMIN_AUTH auth = _ADMIN_AUTH else: auth = service_auth.get_auth_plugin(context) _, _, url = _get_cinderclient_parameters(context) _check_microversion(url, microversion) def cinderclient(context, microversion=None, skip_version_check=False): version = _check_microversion(url, microversion)

commit_message:
vars: Do not pull devel packages on distro installations

The devel packages are only needed to build the pip pacakges so we don't
need them when we install packages straight from the distro repos.

Change-Id: I84bb4c07d2a2abdf517ba24477c2b22a32564129
Implements: blueprint openstack-distribution-packages

commit_message:
Completely stop using the "fake" classic driver in unit tests

This change makes "fake-hardware" the default driver for test nodes
and makes enabled_drivers empty in the base test class.

Note that some unit test coverage for classic drivers is lost because
of this change. It is fine, because the classic drivers themselves
are deprecated and will be removed soon.

Change-Id: I06acb5aed24ef952db3f9e6987e5a90c81e96401

subject: Make timezone-aware configurable
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-08 22:00:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.versionedobjects/commit/1537b1d31cf6aefa26e485e550f835bac250c9c4', 'message': "Make timezone-aware configurable

Some databases such as mysql does not store timezone information in its
DateTime columns. It require applications to canonicalize the timezone
of the datetime object to UTC prior to storing it into the database. Though
oslo_versionedobjects' DateTimeField class offers a tzinfo_aware parameter
to let the application whether they want timezone informaiton or not. That
puts a burden on every application who integrates with oslo_versionedobjects
to funnel that information all the way through from their respective
configuration files. Furthermore, timezone-aware is database-specific, not
field-specific so this information should be globally applicable.

Since oslo_versionedobjects is layered between the DB objecs and application
data models, it is sensical to expose a global config option to specify
whether the DateTimeField should be timezone-aware, or not.

This change introduces a configuration option 'timezone_aware' in the
'oslo_versionedobjects' section to allow applications to specify whether they
want the underlaying datetime data to be timezone aware of not. This option,
if present, will override value specified in the 'tzinfo_aware' parameter.

Change-Id: Id490587a12b776847716a397cd5d5ef29d1b6409
Closes-Bug: #1696417

whether the DateTimeField should be timezone-aware, or not.

'oslo_versionedobjects' section to allow applications to specify whether they
want the underlaying datetime data to be timezone aware of not. This option,
if present, will override value specified in the 'tzinfo_aware' parameter.

In general, it is rather painful to deal with timezone-aware data in the
database, especially since OpenStack services support varity of database
provider. Therefore, we strongly recommend application to start migrating
and standardizing datetime data to UTC and drop the timezone awareness. This
option is designed to help legacy applications to maintain backward
compatibility only. It will default to "False" in the future OpenStack S
release. From OpenStack S release and beyond, legacy applications, or
masochists,  must explicity set this value to "True" if they wish to continue
to support timezone-aware data in the database.

commit_message:
Make timezone-aware configurable

Some databases such as mysql does not store timezone information in its
DateTime columns. It require applications to canonicalize the timezone
of the datetime object to UTC prior to storing it into the database. Though
oslo_versionedobjects' DateTimeField class offers a tzinfo_aware parameter
to let the application whether they want timezone informaiton or not. That
puts a burden on every application who integrates with oslo_versionedobjects
to funnel that information all the way through from their respective
configuration files. Furthermore, timezone-aware is database-specific, not
field-specific so this information should be globally applicable.

Since oslo_versionedobjects is layered between the DB objecs and application
data models, it is sensical to expose a global config option to specify
whether the DateTimeField should be timezone-aware, or not.

This change introduces a configuration option 'timezone_aware' in the
'oslo_versionedobjects' section to allow applications to specify whether they
want the underlaying datetime data to be timezone aware of not. This option,
if present, will override value specified in the 'tzinfo_aware' parameter.

In general, it is rather painful to deal with timezone-aware data in the
database, especially since OpenStack services support varity of database
provider. Therefore, we strongly recommend application to start migrating
and standardizing datetime data to UTC and drop the timezone awareness. This
option is designed to help legacy applications to maintain backward
compatibility only. It will default to "False" in the future OpenStack S
release. From OpenStack S release and beyond, legacy applications, or
masochists,  must explicity set this value to "True" if they wish to continue
to support timezone-aware data in the database.

Change-Id: Id490587a12b776847716a397cd5d5ef29d1b6409
Closes-Bug: #1696417

subject: Improve error reporting for enable-ssh-admin.sh
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-04-25 16:23:42.000000000', 'files': ['tripleoclient/workflows/deployment.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/612b3a4a0e696261f25ce193029fd8696626c289', 'message': "Improve error reporting for enable-ssh-admin.sh

When enable-ssh-admin.sh fails, the error message output is very
unhelpful for figuring out what actually happened.  It seems the
problem is that the info log level is off by default in tripleoclient,
so the log line has no effect unless --debug is also passed.  This
is particularly problematic for enable-ssh-admin.sh, however,
because it can fail intermittently (as described in the attached
bug).  This means that a subsequent run with --debug enabled may
succeed and the underlying problem won't be discovered.

To address this, the log.info call is changed to a plain print like
the other tripleoclient messages that get logged during a deployment,
and the return code is included in the exception message in case that
is helpful for determining what happened.

Change-Id: Id73467a49d750a8748bea7efc2a83bd753f681d1
Partial-Bug: 1766924
"}]
commit_message:
Improve error reporting for enable-ssh-admin.sh

When enable-ssh-admin.sh fails, the error message output is very
unhelpful for figuring out what actually happened.  It seems the
problem is that the info log level is off by default in tripleoclient,
so the log line has no effect unless --debug is also passed.  This
is particularly problematic for enable-ssh-admin.sh, however,
because it can fail intermittently (as described in the attached
bug).  This means that a subsequent run with --debug enabled may
succeed and the underlying problem won't be discovered.

To address this, the log.info call is changed to a plain print like
the other tripleoclient messages that get logged during a deployment,
and the return code is included in the exception message in case that
is helpful for determining what happened.

Change-Id: Id73467a49d750a8748bea7efc2a83bd753f681d1
Partial-Bug: 1766924
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/73/564273/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use upper-constraints in integration tests

If we don't pass -c [upper-constraints] to the commands that deal
with requirements we don't get protection from broken deps.

Change-Id: If47a891077555f4a3a5763a3ff68faef3aa0fa47
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/50/572150/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Added support of volume api_v3 client

* From rocky release projects are consuming the volume featured
  enabled v3 API, Since the earlier code has support
  for v1, v2 and since api_v3 is used in tempest.conf, it will give
  AttributeError: 'Manager' object has no attribute 'volumes_client'.
  The above patch fixes the issue.

* Keep cinder v1 api as tempest plugin is branchless, it would avoid
  breakage if someone is still consuming it.

Closes-Bug: #1775353

Change-Id: Ia9d070a6033a8192112dbaa1704b1de6838051c5

commit_message:
Use generic metadata term instead of config drive

Metadata can be consumed from metadata service and configuration drive.
The spec should refer to the generic metadata term so both mechanisms
are implied.

blueprint multiple-fixed-ips-network-information

Change-Id: If877de77793d5be35ddd2ffc41c7817760b67bfb

deleted_lines: parse the new configuration drive version to benefit from it.version.

commit_message:
Remove old OpenDaylight build references

Versions that have been marked as EOL and are no longer distributed
through the regular channels. There is no longer a need to maintain
them.

This patch removes all references to these old builds.

Change-Id: Ib395c6bec1dea341da712fafc0a566cca9350b95

commit_message:
Remove nitrogen references as it is EOL

Nitrogen has been marked as EOL and is no longer distributed through the
regular channels. There is no longer a need to maintain it.

This patch removes all references to nitrogen from the repo, except one
related to granade that will need to be resolved with another patch.

Change-Id: Iba29b2a5c3c3a13a611ef76b897d93a1e60430a4

commit_message:
Added example blogposts

The usage of privsep isn't really clear nor easy - adding examples
is a good way to avoid bad practices, especially since those two
entries actually provide hints for a common, clean way to use this
library.

Thumb up to Mike Carden for those precious links.

Change-Id: If051ef284ad06aaf44a5eb81242b90af31fdcc06

commit_message:
Add keystone credential-keys and fernet-keys clarification when restoring the Undercloud

We need to be sure that when puppet configures the Undercloud we reuse the keys in the
folders credential-keys and fernet-keys.

Otherwise we will have keystone issues.

Change-Id: Ib9274f28e9163753821abd7b430b2b1117aac622
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/00/572800/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Also, Keystone configuration files need to be synchronized before reinstalling the Undercloud node, so, when applying the puppet config the keys in the folders `credential-keys` and `fernet-keys` don't get regenerated, take into account that the package `openstack-keystone` needs to be installed before synchronizing its configuration data: :: sudo rsync -a /var/tmp/test_bk_down/etc/keystone/ /etc/keystone/

subject: Add a 'trash_output' flag to ansible playbook action
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-06-04 09:38:08.000000000', 'files': ['tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py', 'workbooks/package_update.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/d92b678ca1ca83c97e369a9f72142583c986d785', 'message': "Add a 'trash_output' flag to ansible playbook action

Sometimes, the output is REALLY big. It ends up throwing an error in
MySQL trying to write to the output of the ActionExecution to the
database. Since we're passing the output back via zaqar, we can
just throw this away.

The trash_output flag defaults to false, to maintain the original
behavior.

Change-Id: Id13c7cf52b306891d780243b2562c8ca305aa365
Closes-Bug: #1768913
(cherry picked from commit 89986793a8c3bff9be28cc674923b9f30eab1e89)
"}]
commit_message:
Add a 'trash_output' flag to ansible playbook action

Sometimes, the output is REALLY big. It ends up throwing an error in
MySQL trying to write to the output of the ActionExecution to the
database. Since we're passing the output back via zaqar, we can
just throw this away.

The trash_output flag defaults to false, to maintain the original
behavior.

Change-Id: Id13c7cf52b306891d780243b2562c8ca305aa365
Closes-Bug: #1768913
(cherry picked from commit 89986793a8c3bff9be28cc674923b9f30eab1e89)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/64/572064/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: trash_output: true

Introduce support for multiple fixed-ips in network information found
in metadata service. Network information currently only considers
the first fixed-ip even if instance has more than one fixed-ip per port.

NOTE: The current and proposed formats do not fully address multiple subnets.

Each subnet can have its own routes and default route which create challenges:
* Should all routes be merged in the same "routes" attribute?
* What should be the default route if more than one subnet provides
  a default route? Should we provide all of them?
* What should be the implementation logic an in-guest agent
  use to determine the default route?
* Are there use cases where one default route should be used over the others?
  I'm thinking about NFV or other specialized use cases.

commit_message:
Multiple Fixed-IPs support in network information

Introduce support for multiple fixed-ips in network information found
in metadata service. Network information currently only considers
the first fixed-ip even if instance has more than one fixed-ip per port.

NOTE: The current and proposed formats do not fully address multiple subnets.

Each subnet can have its own routes and default route which create challenges:
* Should all routes be merged in the same "routes" attribute?
* What should be the default route if more than one subnet provides
  a default route? Should we provide all of them?
* What should be the implementation logic an in-guest agent
  use to determine the default route?
* Are there use cases where one default route should be used over the others?
  I'm thinking about NFV or other specialized use cases.

blueprint multiple-fixed-ips-network-information

Change-Id: I135e40edc8850d1dfb352f6b7abd841a4f516888
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/26/312626/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================= Multiple Fixed-IPs support in network information ================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/multiple-fixed-ips-network-info Introduce support for multiple fixed-ips in network information found in metadata service. Network information currently only considers the first fixed-ip even if instance has more than one fixed-ip per port. Problem description =================== Previous work introduced network information concept which removes the need for in-guest agent such as cloud-init to parse a Debian like network configuration file (/etc/network/interfaces) on non-Debian platforms. New network information work unfortunately inherited the limitation of the previous network template system and hasn't been updated to account for ports with multiple fixed IPs. The network information found in metadata service and configuration drive will only have the first fixed IP of the first subnet present. This means it is not possible for an instance to have multiple fixed IPs and have them configured at boot time or after instance is rebuilt. Use Cases --------- A End User can assign multiple fixed IPs to a Neutron port. Those fixed IPs can be part of the same subnet or from different subnets. When creating an instance, Nova will only consider the first fixed IP of the first subnet when building the network information found in the metadata service and configuration drive. A End User have to manually configure the other fixed IPs after the instance is created. This means additional work from the End User before the instance is fully configured and ready for use. If he rebuilds the instance, he will lose his additional fixed ips configuration and will need to manually configure them after rebuild is completed. A End User can assign additional fixed IPs to a Neutron port after the instance creation. Due to the static nature of the configuration drive, he will have to manually configure them in his instance. This is a known limitation of the configuration drive and won't be addressed in this spec. Proposed change =============== This change proposes adding all fixed IPs to network information found in metadata service and configuration drive. Current network information format does not allow for multiple fixed IPs, it will require changes. There is no plan to add support for multiple fixed IPs to the legacy network template unless there is a need and common agreement that it would be easily feasible.

commit_message:
documentation on simulators added

This change re-arranges the documentation along the lines
adopted at OpenStack and also adds some basic hints on
Redfish simulators configuration and use.

Additionally, the sphinx docs building jobs is configured to the
project.

Change-Id: I7ec295d542f003555a1bbf227853936f53966f42
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sushy-tools refs/changes/45/523445/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================= Redfish development tools ========================= This is a set of simple simulation tools aiming at supporting the development and testing of the Redfish protocol implementations and, in particular, Sushy library (https://docs.openstack.org/sushy/). The package ships two simulators - static Redfish responder and cloud-backed virtual Redfish BMC. The static Redfish responder is a simple REST API server which responds the same things to client queries. It is effectively read-only. The virtual Redfish BMC closer resembles the real Redfish-controlled bare-metal machine. All client queries end up at the real cloud the instances of which ultimately simulate the bare-metal machines.
deleted_lines: =========== sushy-tools =========== A set of tools to support the development and test of the Sushy library (https://docs.openstack.org/sushy/)

Second failure is test_ha_router_restart_agents_no_packet_lost which

commit_message:
Mark a fullstack test unstable.

Recently fullstack jobs started showing failures because of two
tests. One was security_groups were not getting applied before it
started testing connectivity b/w instances which is addressed by [1].
Second failure is test_ha_router_restart_agents_no_packet_lost which
is getting debbuged and right now fullstack jobs is unstable because
of that. This patch marks that test unstable for now to avoid rechecks and
load on CI.

[1]. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/572295/

Change-Id: Ib0cc17b8d5aa5366a7478b301d70aa99841dc873
Related-Bug: #1775183
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/68/572568/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.tests import base as test_base @test_base.unstable_test("bug 1775183")

subject: VMware: add support for live migration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-30 08:42:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/c5a1220a07831ef41913f4b9a53cd4c366b33624', 'message': 'VMware: add support for live migration

commit_message:
VMware: add support for live migration

This is a proposal for adding support for live migration in the VMware
driver. When the VMware driver is used, each nova-compute is managing a
single vCenter cluster. For the purposes of this proposal we assume that
all nova-computes are managing clusters under the same vCenter server.
Migrating instances across vCenters is supported starting from vSphere
6.0. We can add support for this as a next-step after this blueprint is
implemented.

blueprint vmware-live-migration

Change-Id: I726b22fb92aedb50a25a3ca38ba92048f05f2a17
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/07/299207/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== VMware live migration ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vmware-live-migration This is a proposal for adding support for live migration in the VMware driver. When the VMware driver is used, each nova-compute is managing a single vCenter cluster. For the purposes of this proposal we assume that all nova-computes are managing clusters under the same vCenter server. Problem description =================== Add support for live migration in the VMware driver. Use Cases --------- As an End User I want to live migrate instances from one vCenter cluster (nova-compute host) to another vCenter cluster (nova-compute host). Proposed change =============== Relocating VMs to another cluster/datastore is a simple matter of calling the RelocateVM_Task() API. The source compute host needs to know the cluster name and the datastore regex of the target compute host. If the instance is located on a datastore shared between the two clusters, it will remain there. Otherwise we will choose a datastore that matches the datastore_regex of the target host and migrate the instance there. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== https://review.openstack.org/#/c/270116/ Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: rgerganov Work Items ---------- It will be implemented in a single patch. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= The VMware CI will provision two nova-computes and will execute the live migration tests from tempest. Documentation Impact ==================== The feature support matrix should be updated to indicate that live migration is supported with the VMware driver. References ========== http://pubs.vmware.com/vsphere-60/topic/com.vmware.wssdk.apiref.doc/vim.VirtualMachine.html#relocate History =======

commit_message:
Remove  RBAC test_volume_list_image_metadata test case

Remove the test_volume_list_image_metadata test case as it duplicates with
test_list_volumes_details_image_metadata in test_volume_metadata_rbac.py.  Also,
test_volume_list_image_metadata does not test list image metadata correctly
since the volume_image_metadata attribute has never been created in the first
place.

Change-Id: I07c3971f5bdb4255105612538e58c79d69daa691

commit_message:
Replace ovsfw tempest job with iptables-hybrid tempest job

In commit [1] openvswitch firewall driver is switched to be
default one used in devstack.
So various tempest jobs will use this driver and it will be
tested.
We now need separate job to test non-default firewall driver
which currently is iptables-hybrid driver.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568297/

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568297/
Change-Id: I6061a173c95c8a41a61bfa298ae5964cc9b5d2e8

commit_message:
Driver usage example is not correct

In the documentation it defines 'driver.slow-driver' and
'driver.fast-driver'.  Then, however, when their implementation
status is indicated it has 'driver-slow-driver' and
'driver-faster-driver' which isn't correct.

Change-Id: I01f4d268eed735cc8c013d016e4aac69aa272b33

commit_message:
Fix constraints error in pep8 job

It seems that the constraints file needs to be referenced in deps
and not install_command.

subject: neutron: Use openvswitch firewall driver by default
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-05-14 14:17:04.000000000', 'files': ['lib/neutron', 'lib/neutron_plugins/ovs_base'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/a99ab7002cfea539e035e203c0d05415fac3eb6a', 'message': "neutron: Use openvswitch firewall driver by default

openvswitch firewall has been in Neutron tree since Newton and has gone
through lots of improvements since including simple upgrade path from
the iptables hybrid driver.

We have a tempest job running in Neutron tree with openvswitch firewall
that's been voting and stable for a while. For neutron_tempest_plugin,
we have had the openvswitch firewall in use since the beginning.

This patch proposes openvswitch firewall driver to become a default
driver for openvswitch agent deployments.

Change-Id: If26d0180e459210511f25f1faa83dd8ccea25ff4
"}]
commit_message:
neutron: Use openvswitch firewall driver by default

openvswitch firewall has been in Neutron tree since Newton and has gone
through lots of improvements since including simple upgrade path from
the iptables hybrid driver.

We have a tempest job running in Neutron tree with openvswitch firewall
that's been voting and stable for a while. For neutron_tempest_plugin,
we have had the openvswitch firewall in use since the beginning.

This patch proposes openvswitch firewall driver to become a default
driver for openvswitch agent deployments.

Change-Id: If26d0180e459210511f25f1faa83dd8ccea25ff4

commit_message:
Fix README setup.py check error

The releases repo added a validation for PyPI meta files.
The command line is "python3 setup.py check --restructuredtext --strict".
It seems '.. include::' directive cannot work in this check
and it blocks the release process.

LINKS.rst is simple enough, so this commit move the content of LINKS.rst
into README.rst and doc/source/index.rst, while they are duplicated.

This is a workaround to make Rocky-2 release work and
hopefully we can find a better solution in near future.

Change-Id: I381b4494744c2f069227e83ae02f4c956633f4b9

commit_message:
[kibana] enforce index creation for ELK > 5 (debian)

The default index isn't created automatically when using
ELK > 5.x. This commit adds a new task into the post-deploy
taskset to force the creation of the default index.

This patch also enforces the kibana config to set index
as defaultIndex without the need for the defaultIndex property
to already exists , preventing the error exposed on the public bug.

Also added a new option named kibana_default_index_options, with
a default index.mapper.dynamic set to true, this option
can be extended by the operator and they will be applied to the index.

Change-Id: Ica63a5fb30947f7ebae6cf8c80500a7dd0907211
Closes-Bug: #1772687
Signed-off-by: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@linaro.org>

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/44/571244/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * glance_store library: completed. (For details, see the `glance project py35 tracking etherpad <https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/glance-pike-python35-goal>`_.) * python-glanceclient: completed. (For details, see the `glance project py35 tracking etherpad <https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/glance-pike-python35-goal>`_.) * glance: not completed. - Glance is affected by the eventlet ssl-handshake-drop problem in py35 (see `Bug #1482633 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1482633>`_) - Fix will have to occur in eventlet (not sure that will actually happen) - We've reconfigured the functional tests that were being skipped when run under py35 and will run them as their own non-voting gate job named 'glance-eventlet-ssl-handshake-broken-py35' so that it's obvious that this issue exists (and, more optimistically, we can easily detect when it's fixed). (See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/571040/) - There is a workaround, namely, use something like HAProxy to do SSL termination before calls are forwarded to Glance.

commit_message:
[WIP] Remove castellan's keystoneauth dependency

As part of being incorporated into Oslo, the keystoneauth dependency
should be removed.

This patch also works towards implementing pluggable drivers in
oslo_config.

Change-Id: I62c4bcaa63a8ff53592c319833e1cde8f3c7126d
Patially-Implements: I9833f16088289147f38ea0dd03b2ba56106aa9b5

LOG.error(msg) raise exception.Forbidden(msg) if self._barbican_client and self._current_context == context: return self._barbican_client try: auth = self._get_keystone_auth(context) sess = session.Session(auth=auth, verify=self.conf.barbican.verify_ssl) self._barbican_endpoint = self._get_barbican_endpoint(auth, sess) self._barbican_client = barbican_client_import.Client( session=sess, endpoint=self._barbican_endpoint) self._current_context = context # TODO(pbourke): more fine grained exception handling - we are eating # tracebacks here except Exception as e: LOG.error("Error creating Barbican client: %s", e) raise exception.KeyManagerError(reason=e) self._base_url = self._create_base_url(auth, sess, self._barbican_endpoint) return self._barbican_client def _get_keystone_auth(self, context): if context.__class__.__name__ is 'KeystonePassword': return identity.Password( auth_url=context.auth_url, username=context.username, password=context.password, user_id=context.user_id, user_domain_id=context.user_domain_id, user_domain_name=context.user_domain_name, trust_id=context.trust_id, domain_id=context.domain_id, domain_name=context.domain_name, project_id=context.project_id, project_name=context.project_name, project_domain_id=context.project_domain_id, project_domain_name=context.project_domain_name, reauthenticate=context.reauthenticate) elif context.__class__.__name__ is 'KeystoneToken': return identity.Token( auth_url=context.auth_url, token=context.token, trust_id=context.trust_id, domain_id=context.domain_id, domain_name=context.domain_name, project_id=context.project_id, project_name=context.project_name, project_domain_id=context.project_domain_id, project_domain_name=context.project_domain_name, reauthenticate=context.reauthenticate) # this will be kept for oslo.context compatibility until # projects begin to use utils.credential_factory elif context.__class__.__name__ is 'RequestContext': return identity.Token( auth_url=self.conf.barbican.auth_endpoint, token=context.auth_token, project_id=context.project_id, project_name=context.project_name, project_domain_id=context.project_domain_id, project_domain_name=context.project_domain_name) else: msg = _("context must be of type KeystonePassword, " "KeystoneToken, or RequestContext.") LOG.error(msg) raise exception.Forbidden(reason=msg) def _get_barbican_endpoint(self, auth, sess): if self.conf.barbican.barbican_endpoint: return self.conf.barbican.barbican_endpoint else: service_parameters = {'service_type': 'key-manager', 'service_name': 'barbican', 'interface': 'public'} return auth.get_endpoint(sess, **service_parameters) def _create_base_url(self, auth, sess, endpoint): if self.conf.barbican.barbican_api_version: api_version = self.conf.barbican.barbican_api_version else: discovery = auth.get_discovery(sess, url=endpoint) raw_data = discovery.raw_version_data() if len(raw_data) == 0: msg = _( "Could not find discovery information for %s") % endpoint LOG.error(msg) raise exception.KeyManagerError(reason=msg) latest_version = raw_data[-1] api_version = latest_version.get('id') if endpoint[-1] != '/': endpoint += '/' base_url = urllib.parse.urljoin( endpoint, api_version) return base_url def create_key(self, context, algorithm, length, barbican_client = self._get_barbican_client(context) def create_key_pair(self, context, algorithm, length, barbican_client = self._get_barbican_client(context) def store(self, context, managed_object, expiration=None): barbican_client = self._get_barbican_client(context) def _get_secret(self, context, object_id): barbican_client = self._get_barbican_client(context) def delete(self, context, managed_object_id): barbican_client = self._get_barbican_client(context) def list(self, context, object_type=None, metadata_only=False): barbican_client = self._get_barbican_client(context)

Update auth_uri option to www_authenticate_uri

commit_message:
Check RST as part of linting

Check our RST files so that uploading to PyPI works fine with a linter

commit_message:
Retry decorator fix for autoscale delete

deallocate-network-retry

retry fix for VM going to ERROR state during auto-scale delete instance

Delete issued to building server leaves the instance in error state due to
not able to deallocate network error.During auto-scale delete, some of
the machines go into ERROR state rather than being deleted.This happens
once in a while during deletion of the instances at scale.Log line for
the failure is 'Setting instance vm_state to ERROR',
Failure in do_terminate_instance.

Change-Id: Ie27a19113b600a2e8222d39a5633504fd775a5ef
Closes-Bug: #1765942

commit_message:
Switch carbon and nitrogen to release

This is a combination of 2 commits.

This is the 1st commit message:

devstack: teach how to handle latest ODL release

This is the commit message #2:

Switch carbon and nitrogen to release

Carbon and nitrogen ODL versions were moved in nexus from snapshot to
release as they are no longer maintained.

This patch allows retrieval from there instead.

Change-Id: I3c6e25d2ce147bf3159606e6e6f490e5249e8226

commit_message:
Add validation to avoid having an Overcloud with underscores.

We need to ensure the Overcloud is fixed before proceeding with
an Upgrade.

Change-Id: Id7bbbe0df21de16c4eab5c9a049c0d853443ff23
Closes-Bug: 1775404
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations refs/changes/74/572774/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- - hosts: undercloud vars: metadata: name: Check Overcloud name with underscores description: > This validation will check if there is deployed an Overcloud using underscores in it's name. groups: - pre-upgrade tasks: - name: Check if the Overcloud name has underscores shell: | source ~/stackrc overcloud_name=$(openstack stack list -f json | jq -r '.[]["Stack Name"]' | grep -Po "_") if [[ ! -z "$overcloud_name" ]]; then naming_error='Underscore_Not_Allowed'; fi echo $naming_error; register: naming_error changed_when: false - name: Check Overcloud name fail: msg: > Overcloud name can't contain underscores as they are not supported in newer versions. Update the Overcloud name with a string without underscores before proceeding with the upgrade. when: - naming_error.stdout == 'Underscore_Not_Allowed'

commit_message:
Document the China registry mirror

Kolla always fails to pull kolla images. This patch is to document
how to use the China registry mirror to avoid the failure of pulling
kolla images.

Change-Id: Ib31b3ee6183c12467df4f28f8dff438ed6e9d41c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/87/572087/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: In some countries like China, Kolla maight fail due to unable to pull images from `Docker Hub <https://hub.docker.com/u/kolla/>`__. There is a workround to solve this issue: .. code-block:: console sudo mkdir -p /etc/docker sudo tee /etc/docker/daemon.json <<-'EOF' { "registry-mirrors": ["https://registry.docker-cn.com"] } EOF sudo systemctl daemon-reload sudo systemctl restart docker .. end

commit_message:
Implements: adds FIBRE_CHANNEL support

This change adds the FIBRE_CHANNEL as a supported protocol to the
brick cinderclient extension. The change was tested with a 3PAR
storage backend and a Debian 9.2 Host OS installation.

Cinder volume driver used for testing was:

 cinder.volume.drivers.hpe.hpe_3par_fc.HPE3PARFCDriver

Storage backend hardware used for testing was:

 HP 3PAR 7400c

Amended to resolve pep8/documentation errors as reported by Zuul

Change-Id: Ie7e8b7e3141600de0d711a7bca94256d4d7f58ab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-brick-cinderclient-ext refs/changes/12/572412/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
